Award.AwardTitle: Advancing Understanding of Semiconducting Oxide Nano-Heterostructure Gas Sensors
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: This project has direct technological benefits to society by enabling the accelerated development of selective, low-power portable gas sensors. This work is purposely structured to disrupt the cycle of trial-and-error materials discovery in gas sensors by developing a fundamental understanding of the sensing mechanisms to enable bottom-up design and engineering of nanomaterials toward specific applications. The knowledge gained from this research provides crucial contributions to the field seeking to: (1) enhance rapid detection of leaks of toxic or flammable gases that could otherwise cause massive environmental damage; (2) enable real-time automated monitoring of food freshness to reduce food waste and aid sustainability, and (3) facilitate deployment of portable sensors capable of rapid screening for biomarkers in exhaled breath that correlate with a range of health conditions and cancers, aiding early detection efforts in populations lacking easy access to advanced health care technology. The two graduate students funded by this project are being developed into future leaders in a U.S. sensor community that is increasingly yielding leadership to international efforts in Japan, South Korea, China, and several groups in Europe. Specifically, they will become experts in nanomaterial electrical measurements and state-of-the-art electronic properties characterization via electron microscopy.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: A recent surge in nanomaterials research has developed many novel methods for synthesizing semiconducting oxides into nanostructures, especially with combinations of materials into a single structure, termed a nano-heterostructure. However, the focus on new synthesis methods has led to a largely trial-and-error approach toward materials discovery for gas sensor applications with little fundamental understanding of the underlying mechanisms. The primary focus of this research is to develop and publish a comprehensive and unifying model for interactions of gases with nano-heterostructures that will provide a framework which enables the rest of the field to more effectively design new structures and ultimately accelerate their implementation into devices. This project seeks fundamental knowledge from proven sensor materials engineered into nano-heterostructures by (1) using state-of-the-art high-resolution electron microscopy techniques to evaluate the electronic structure and properties of these materials on an individual nanoparticle basis; (2) utilizing electrical measurements on single nanowires and clusters of nanowires to separate contributions of interfaces from the bulk and mapping the effects of each oxide constituent as a function of environmental conditions; and (3) building a model of the electronic interactions at the gas-oxide and oxide-oxide interfaces truly representative of nanomaterials and not based on bulk ideal properties. Additionally, an open-access on-line database is being constructed of resistive-type gas sensor published results to aid researchers in the field in identifying trends in materials properties and disseminating important results, as well as helping industries to identify the most promising technologies for a specific application.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF project titled ?Advancing Understanding of Semiconducting Oxide Nano-Heterostructure Gas Sensors? investigated semiconducting oxides for gas sensor applications. Fundamental knowledge was furthered by developing a database to preform large scale cross-comparisons of sensing data, investigating mechanisms dictating selective gas detection to form predictive models for gas sensor behavior, and testing the sensitivity of nano-scale materials for core-shell and other types of heterostructure architectures.

An Open-access Database Of Resistive-type Sensors (ODORS; www.odorsdatabase.com) has been developed during this project to compile and compare data related to the synthesis, fabrication, and performance of resistive-type sensors from available literature. The user input forms available for data input of these sensing parameters are shown in images 1 and 2. Sensing data from 180 published studies have been input into the database. These studies have been compared to identify various sensing trends. The trends discovered from these analyses were used to direct experimental research efforts for both undergraduate senior projects as well as the graduate students funded by this project. The ODORS database was a fundamental research tool for remote work during the 2020 Covid-19 global pandemic.

Selectivity in resistive-type sensing has been investigated by modifying material selection and ratio for commonly studied semiconducting metal oxides as composites. Shifts in selectivity between gas analytes were observed for different materials systems and depending on the ratio of oxides chosen. A model was developed to describe these shifts in selectivity based on cancellation of conduction channels between p-type and n-type oxides. This investigation will allow for predictive design of resistive-type sensors by utilizing a combination of oxides to achieve desired gas selectivity.

Conduction mechanisms in resistive type metal oxide core-shell nanowires were investigated by using different shell layers. Sensitivity difference has been observed when exposed to hydrogen gas depending on the thickness of the shell layers. Sensitivity difference has been analyzed with respect to the width of the depletion layer formed at the heterojunction interface and height of the potential barrier formed in n-type metal oxides. These are fundamental parameters that can help in understanding the effect of the heterojunction interface formed in core-shell nanowires for resistive type gas sensing. This study will help in designing n-type core-shell nanowires to achieve better response. Images 3 and 4 show TEM micrographs of core-shell ZnO-SnO2 and SnO2-TiO2 nanowire used for sensor testing.

This project funded two Ph.D. students, graduating in 2021, produced several publications, provided research experience for several undergraduate researchers, and resulted in collaboration with other research groups both within Ohio State University and with other research institutions. The results obtained from this research have been disseminated to the public via conference presentations and lab demonstrations throughout the duration of the project. Furthermore, the database (ODORS) and the dissertations produced under this project are available for future research in semiconducting metal oxides.
